Here's an actual review of the game instead of overused memes.

It's a PvE, match-based system with single-player or up to 4-player coop (including matchmaking to find groups.)

You create a character with an average customization system, and seem to gain currency + experience by completing trials to unlock cosmetics, classes, class upgrades, and general perks to augment gameplay.

Gameplay consists of varied maps, with objectives you need to accomplish while enemies roam around, collecting resources to aid you through the trial. Enemies and traps are scattered all throughout the map and can create different experiences each playthrough.

I've played around three matches and had a blast with randoms, and with friends. The game optimization is great too, and I haven't experienced any technical issues or stutters.

Looking forward to playing much more of this game.

First of all do not compare this game to dead by daylight or expect it to be a dead by daylight replacement. I love that there is a narrative that the game is clear about as you start, sure the multiplayer aspect and gameplay loop is there but as the updates progress more lore and files release and you understand more about the Murkoff and events that link to the first and second Outlast games since in the timeline the game happens well before those two. However let's say you never had interest in the single player games and jumped straight into Outlast trials.

The trials themselves are a bit lengthy, this is a game where you set sufficient time for maybe 1-5 runs of the trials at least because these trials take a while to complete. Much of the enjoyment comes from interactions with the NPC enemies that roam the trials as you can't fight back beyond stunning them out of attacking your friends / killing them or staggering them with an object or three of the six rigs you are provided. Ultimately in the trials you want to do them without getting hurt and triggering traps for a high grade and the gameplay loop basically revolves around going in, doing the trials and side tasks for currency and levels for tickets to upgrade your talents and drip and bedroom furniture. At the time reviewing though the game is VERY generous with cosmetics which is refreshing, community still pretty active though unfortunately for solo players the game can't be played offline. 

The game can be scary too, even if you get used to the game at times there are moments that may catch you off guard due to the unpredictable nature of some of the NPC, the max difficulty is pretty hard as well, it is recommended you spend a lot of time learning the game on standard difficulty too.

I normally stay away from horror or gore focused games, so I started the game with some hesitation. The beginning is very intense, especially the tutorial. The dark rooms, the constant pressure and the unsettling sound design made me think I would stop fairly quickly, simply because the genre usually does not work for me. After I started playing with friends and got used to the atmosphere, my view changed much faster than expected. Playing in a group makes the experience more enjoyable and less overwhelming, even though the game also works well solo. What surprised me most was how motivating the gameplay loop is. Completing objectives together feels rewarding and the game manages to stay tense without becoming frustrating.

One of the reasons I keep coming back are the daily and weekly tasks. They add variety and give you a reason to log in regularly. The seasonal content also adds long term progression. Collecting stamps to unlock new outfits and cosmetics is simple but fun and it gives the game a bit more depth without turning it into a grind. The developers deserve credit for supporting the game so actively. There are regular content updates, new events and small improvements that show the game is still being worked on. Visually, the game looks very good. The environments are detailed, the lighting is strong and the overall atmosphere is exactly what you would expect from a horror title. Performance has been stable for me as well. The only real bug I ran into was falling through the floor once when I died, but it never happened again and did not impact the overall experience.

In the end, the game exceeded my expectations. I thought I would not last long because I am not a horror fan, but now I find myself returning to it on a daily base. With the combination of coop, content updates and a progression system, I can easily recommend it, even to players who normally avoid this genre!

I did not want this game. I am not remotely a gore fan, I haven't even watched the most popular films. 

Outlast Trials was a Halloween gift, an attempt for our group of friends to do escape games together throughout the season. 

To say I was skeptical is putting it mildly, and my attempt at the tutorial ended up in screaming, hiding, and bailing out. 

Seventy two hours later, I've got most of the achievements, and I play at least a match every night. 

Outlast Trials is not for the faint of heart, the content is incredibly graphic, certainly not for children. At a certain point, I do think you can ignore that element and focus on the objectives or even on the story itself and what it means- that being a very clear antifascist, anticapitalist, prodiversity message throughout. I think some people will appreciate it, and others will ignore it for the base imagery.

If you're into games like Dead By Daylight or Friday the 13th, you'll probably like this. Imagine an escape room with hide and seek and the ability to fight back. 

You can play longer or shorter trials, some of which you can get through in under fifteen minutes, and you can play solo, with friends, or through matchmaking, all are very viable. 

There's even a new mode you can invade other trials in, it's a lot of fun, and if you're looking for something a little less complicated than a trial to play really quick alone or with friends, it's a great option. 

Something I had not expected that's brought a lot of enjoyment has been the "sleep room". Between trials you'll go back and hang out with others, randoms, and whoever is in your group. You can play chess, arm wrestle, play pong, or even challenge each other on a Stroop test. 

Possibly the best part of the sleep room is that you'll be able to customize your own room. There are in game purchases for coins to unlock catalogues faster, but if you look around you'll find you can actually get through it all without making any purchases if you spend your coins wisely. 

Despite the nature of the game, I currently have the coziest Christmas room decked out in 50s aesthetic. 

You'll also find a mirror for player customization in your room, little outfits, or separate items. You'll win some through trials, achievements, badges, seasonal events, or filling out your catalogues, same as room decorations. There's not much customization where face or body type are concerned, but I think you'll find it doesn't really matter all that much. 

Overall, I think anyone who likes to be scared should try it, even if you think it may be a bit much, especially if you'll have friends along for the ride. It's a great game with a lot of fun features to keep you entertained and on your toes.

** FIRST IMPRESSION **

*The Outlast Trials* ended up being way better than I expected. I knew it would be creepy - it's Outlast, after all - but the way this game mixes atmosphere, teamwork, and outright panic makes it stand out not just in the series, but in the horror genre in general.

** THE EXPERIENCE **

The atmosphere is honestly incredible. Every location feels like it was handcrafted to mess with your nerves. The whole Cold Warâ€“era setting combined with Murkoffâ€™s twisted experiments gives the game a really unique vibe that keeps you hooked and uncomfortable at the same time.

Everything from the lighting to the sound design keeps you on edge. You hear a whisper or a sudden bang and immediately start questioning your next move. The enemies feel smarter and more reactive than in previous Outlast games, so even familiar situations somehow stay tense.

Between trials, the Sleep Room hub is this weird mix of calm and unsettlingâ€”a place to breathe, but not fully relax. It creates a nice rhythm between the chaos of the trials and the moments where you regroup and prepare.

The multiplayer aspect is where the game really shines. Playing with others doesnâ€™t kill the fear at all, it actually makes everything more chaotic and stressful in the best way possible. Trying to complete objectives while someone screams that an enemy is right behind them somehow manages to be both terrifying and hilarious. With the recently added option to make your own trials the game feels even more unpredictable, and when your team finally pulls off a good run, it feels like a real accomplishment.

The progression system is surprisingly satisfying too. You always feel like you're working toward something, and it keeps you wanting to complete "just one more run". Once you have reached level 99 you are able to relapse (prestige) which increases your displayed relapse level (prestige level) for some bragging rights and resets your level progression to level 1, so the grind to level 99 starts all over again. Every time you relapse (prestige) you get 1 permanent unlock which enables you to unlock one of your favorite upgrades. Make sure you choose wisely!  

** THE TEAM BEHIND THE GAME **

Red Barrels really knocked it out of the park with this one. You can tell they put a lot of care into expanding the Outlast world without losing what made it memorable. The game feels polished yet still raw and disturbing in all the right ways.

What really stands out, though, is how committed the developers are to keeping the game alive. They keep pushing out updates, new content, seasonal events - you name it. Itâ€™s clear they listen to the community and genuinely want to keep the experience fresh for players.

** FINAL THOUGHTS **

The Outlast Trials is easily one of the most intense and enjoyable horror experiences Iâ€™ve had in years. It captures the classic Outlast terror but adds new layers of teamwork, tension, and replayability. If youâ€™re into horror games that really make your heart race, this one is absolutely worth picking up. Just be ready for some genuinely nerve-wracking moments.

The game focuses on cooperative survival horror inside a controlled testing environment. You complete objectives while avoiding hostile NPCs and environmental traps. Runs generate stress through constant pursuit and limited resources.

Stealth is essential. Direct confrontation ends quickly. You hide in lockers, crouch behind cover, and monitor patrol routes. Noise attracts enemies. Light exposes you. Success depends on timing and route discipline.

Tools provide small advantages. Stun items, healing syringes, and lockpicks buy seconds. Resource scarcity forces careful use. Crafting is limited but useful. Improvised solutions matter.

Enemy variety shapes tension. Some foes patrol. Others chase aggressively. Special enemies disrupt hiding. Behavioral patterns require observation. Mistakes cascade fast.

Visual design uses darkness and narrow corridors. Flashlights create limited safety. Blood, graffiti, and alarms build atmosphere. Performance remains stable. Level layouts blend maze structure with scripted set pieces.

Audio drives fear. Footsteps, screams, and alarms provide direction cues. Voice acting reinforces threat tone. Music spikes during chases. Headphones improve spatial awareness.

The game suits players who enjoy cooperative stealth under pressure. It is punishing but fair. Randomization supports replay. Solo play is possible but stressful. Best experienced with coordinated teammates.

Definitely one of my top favorite coop games especially in a horror genre. Even if you don't always directly work with others during trials you all still work towards the same goals which is completing objectives so you can escape. Rigs can be used to assist yourself or others. Helping each other when in major danger of deadly enemies. New players will definitely have a fun time when working alongside others and share the scares for the first time. Even better if you have a crew of friends wanting to give a try together for the first time. Community is more on the positive side despite of the new Invasion update since it's more PVE focused opposed to PvP which is still very new to the scene. Experienced players are more likely to help especially if you ask for it and need some guidance. Coop actions is definitely a cool concept to have in the game that way to create shortcuts.
HORROR
This being an Outlast game. There's no short supply of scares especially for new folk wanting to try it out for the first time. Creepy as well as deadly environments, lore and enemies. You got traps to be on the lookout for and there's different genre of enemies. Regular in trial enemies such as "Grunts" and "Giants" that patrol to find and kill Reagent players. "Special Ex Pops" that spawn into trials for a duration to cause reagents trouble and then finally "Prime Assets" basically the boss enemies for the different areas that Trials take place in. You'll be learning how each enemy works and how to deal with them over time.
GAMEPLAY
Gameplay is simple yet can be tricky for newcomers since it's hard to learn while under stress and panicking from the horror experience they'll go through. Simply as a Reagent you run and hide from enemies while completing all kinds of unique objectives to progress in a trial in order to get out. You're able to use Rigs that can be selected in the Play HUB before entering trials that can give a huge edge whether dealing with enemies, the environment, allies or objectives. Players can find useable items around the map to help them recover, get away from danger or even sometimes an item that's mandatory to complete a puzzle for an objective. There is a progression system for your character and even a prestige system if you find yourself wanting to keep playing for more rewards. Multiple endings for the game. Lots of lore if you enjoy learning about the world in Outlast Trials. 
CHALLENGE?
The trials can be made more difficult by your choice if you wanna challenge yourself or alongside your crew. You can start by increasing difficulty which will add "Modifiers" mixing up the trials with all kinds of effects whether it be limiting items, affecting the environment itself or increasing enemy quantity as well as their damage etc. You can even create your own trials and go nuts to make the hardest trial you can think of or simply what you think would be fun.
MONEY FOR COSMETICS?
NO it is NOT necessary to put money into the game in order to earn cool cosmetics or rewards in the game. The devs with this current update however are now allowing players IF they want to spend money they can to get cosmetics right away. You naturally earn cosmetics and rewards by simply playing the game and using the earned currency to purchase things from a multiple catalogs that also give you "Coins" to buy more catalogs and earn more free rewards.
Recommend?
YES if you wanna have a good scare, enjoy progression, lore or simply want to play with some friends and have a laugh while being spooked then give this game a try. I always enjoy meeting new players and getting to see their experience for the first time.

I'll preface by saying that these types of games are completely foreign to me. Realistic graphics? Not my thing. A game seemingly tailor made for people who only watch cartel beheadings? You've already pretty much lost me. That said, this game is pretty good.

The gore can be a bit much to the point of being self-indulgent, but it tries to craft an uncomfortable setting and does what it set out to do. You will inevitably get over the initial shock value of the bloodstained corridors; Binding of Isaac came to mind in how its gore and body horror became an afterthought on repeated playthroughs. That said, there's still some truly visceral imagery that will snap you out of that desensitized haze. Definitely not for everyone by any means. If you are not acquainted with stressful situations or have lived a life sheltered from life's adversities, this game may prove to be a challenge. I've learned that through my repeated therapies. It can get incredibly nerve-wracking, especially on higher difficulties. You will inevitably struggle with the hordes of enemies thwarting your objectives; it pushed me to my limit. That said, when everything comes together and you outsmart the enemies while getting an A+ on a mission, it's a hit of serotonin that keeps me going.

Also helps that this game isn't super complicated, it's fairly straightforward. Just make sure you have a group of friends to play it with. You [i]can[/i] play solo, but you will probably get frustrated when enemies inevitably camp the objective and you don't have some buds to lure them away. Definitely possible, but the game is clearly not designed with solo play in mind.

An at times annoyingly repetitive co-op horror game with an Outlast skin pasted over it. Every trial consists of repeating mindless and repetitive objectives with almost zero direction whatsoever. Often times you'll need to collect keys or complete puzzles, all marked with a certain symbol of which there'll be red herring ones that exist solely to waste your time. You're actively encouraged to run around like a headless chicken until you just happen to run across whatever you're looking for. You're almost never required to actually think about what you're supposed to be doing, all you do is shut your brain off and mindlessly press buttons until you're suddenly done the trial.

All of this was still serviceable until a certain trial, "Pleasure the Prosecutor," which may be the most annoying set of tasks I've ever had to do in a co-op game. The mission consists of tracking down enemies across a large map, using a microwave gun three times on them to blow up their heads and take a key from their corpse. These enemies run away after every shock so you have to track them down three times in order to get the key. You then use this key to open a room, pull a lever, and stand in the room until a progress meter reaches 100%, keep in mind that the levers will automatically pull back down twice during the duration of this and you have to track down which ones turned off and turn them back on all while evading enemies. Completing this task gets you one piece of a mannequin. Yeah, just one. You have to do this three times. The whole process of tracking down the same enemy three different times across the map to get a key so you can wait in a room and pull levers three times so that you can get one piece of a mannequin has to be done three separate times, successfully taking a game that already had a very repetitive gameplay loop and making it egregiously annoying. No amount of banter between friends means anything when all of you are just annoyed because the level is absolutely abysmal.

The consistency of content being added to the game is appreciated but none of it truly feels unique enough to justify spending a significant amount of time playing. It's a fun enough game to play with friends if you can get it on sale, but in this case, your time is more valuable than your money. If you don't enjoy losing your mind doing repetitive objectives, I'd avoid this one like the plague and just hope they can bring it back with an Outlast 3.

How to turn off Invasion Mode outside of Experimental Therapy:

Open either the Terminal (with Tab) or the Menu (with Esc)

Click on 'Privacy Options' in the bottom right corner.

Click on the arrows next to both 'Allow invasion by anyone' and 'Allow invasion by friends', until they display 'OFF'.

Congratulations! You can now play the game.
